addressleaf.section:
To the right honorable my very singular good Lord,
e L. Burghley, Lord highe Treasuro
r
of England.

23 Martij
1590
. M
r
Bodeleie from
e Haghe./

page.lettertext:
fol.279r
May it please yo
r
good L. a letter from yo
w
of
the 9 was delivered unto me
e 21 of this
moneth: wherin yo
w
will me from her
Ma
tie
to expostulat w
t
e
states,
for their slacknes
in relieving
e towne of
Ostend.
At sundrie
times before, both her Ma
tie
by her owne letters,
and also yo
r
L. in
e name of her Hig
nes
hath
required my endevo
rs
, to
e self same purpose.
And for mine owne part I doe assure yo
r
L.
there was never any mater, that I moved so often,
or so instantly urged, as that of Ostend. But
howe
e states stand affected, their letter to her
Hig
nes
w
ch
they sent by
S
r
John Norreis
, and an
other from my self, w
ch
was written to yo
r
L.
will certifie sufficiently. They are all of one
judgement, that the Governo
r
hath no cause,
to presse her Ma
tie
so farre, for any doubt of
e
Enemie. Nevertheles upon this motion nowe
againe, w
ch
I have made from her Ma
tie
they have
yelded to
e sending thither of two companies
of their owne nation: upon condition, that
when they shalbe prepared to goe into
e filde,
they may be returned heere againe. I have
also obtened, that suche provision of powder
and corne, as before they did but promise in
general termes, shall be presently sent thither,
by order out of
Zeland.
Howbeit they doe
flatly avoutche, that
e publicke Magasine of
e towne, hath bin alwaies by
e contrey suffi-
ciently stoared; but that it hath bin consumed
in privat uses, by those of
e Garrison, without
permission from hens, and against
e custome
of
e contrey. Moreover to suche effect as before,
they have written once againe, both into Zeland,
fol.279v
and elswhere, that good enquirie may be made,
to learne
e Enemies proceedinges in those quar-
ters of
Flanders:
to
e end they may ordene,
w
at
soever shall be requisit. For as nowe, they
say, they knowe nothing of ether siege, or sur-
prise, or other enterprise towardes. And though
e
Governo
r
hath informed her Ma
tie
of many
occasions of feare, yet nether he himself did
ever write so muche to them, nor any one of their
officers, that sojourne in
e Garrison: whiche are
as vigilant as may be, in every suche occasion.
S
r
Edward Norreis is a gentleman
of that merit, that every man hath knowen, and
to me in particular very frindly affected.
for w
ch
I may be thought both very unkind and
inconsiderat, to advertise any mater, that is ne-
ther precisely w
t
in
e compasse of my charge, and
may seeme in some sort to touche
e credit of his
actions. But for as muche as my meaning, being
construed right, is sincere and frindly, and
my duty to her Ma
tie
must make me sett a part
all privat respectes: and because yo
r
L. I
knowe, will make no further mention, then is
needefull, of my name, I will signifie somw
at
,
howe it standeth at this present, between S
r
Edward and
e states. It is a generall
order of
e contrey, w
ch
every Governo
r
of any
towne, that belongeth to
e states, is strictly
sworen to observe, That they shall not meddle
more or lesse, w
t
e maters of Contribution of
Impost and Accise, or of any point that shall per-
tene to
e Civill pollicie of
e place. Not only
those that are Governo
rs
deputed by the states,
but they that have
e charge of
e Cautionarie
fol.280r
townes, are in that respect restrained, by a spe-
cial article of
e Treaty. The case is very evi-
dent, and there is no Governo
r
of
e contrey,
at
doth seeke to be exempted. Nevertheles S
r
Edward
Norreis doth usurpe that autoritie, and being
often required to take an other course, doth
seeme to heede it so litle, as they have entred
into speeche to remove him from thens. He pre-
tendeth unto them, that he doth nothing of him-
self, but by order from home, and by her Mat
ies
direction: whiche doth very muche amuse the
Councel of state
, and doth foster in many an
old rooted jalousie, That her Ma
ties
ministers
would be masters of their townes, and bring their
contrey into servitude, as muche as
e Spaniard,
whose government they abjured for defense
of their liberties. In effect I knowe their
humo
r
so well, and I see they are so peremptorie
in all their purposes, as unles they be obeied in
their owne jurisdiction, they care not if
e towne
should falle to
e Enemie. And this in truth
is
e chiefest occasion, that they hearken so un-
willingly to any motion of
e Governo
r
. For
otherwise, they knowe the importance of
e place
as well as is possible, and, they say, they will
tender it, as muche as shall be requisit, if they
may be respected as by all other Governo
rs
.
The Governo
r
, they imagine, to serve his privat
turne, is an autor to her Ma
tie
of many wrong
impressions, and devised alarmes, making his
designe to manege all thinges alone, and to con-
vert
e benefit of
e generall meanes, to his privat
uses, or at lest to be disposed, as he himself w
t
out
them shall thinke most expedient. I am alwaies
fol.280v
earnest to persuade them otherwise, alleaging
his want of experience in
e affaires of these con-
treis, and other mater of excuse: as I have also
written to himself, and wished him in any wise
to w
t
stand these beginninges, and to applie his
course somwhat more, to
e nature of this Gover-
ment, but because his answear hath bin, that
he frameth all his doinges, w
t
e notice of her Hig
nes
I have nothing to replie. For my self I see not,
nor I can not conjecture, howe her Ma
ties
service
may be bettered by it: but I am very muche
afraid, unles they may have their willes, the
end will be but trouble, and danger to
e place.
The consideration wherof and of my duty to her
Ma
tie
and my confidence w
t
all
at yo
r
L. will
suppresse my name in this mater, doth enforce
me to impart this advertisment at length.
Besides I thought not impertinent, to give yo
r
L. to consider,
e copie of a letter, w
ch
e Councel
of late hath sent unto
e Governo
r
.
Two daies past I receaved a letter of
e 22 of
Fe
b
written at
Dresden;
from
S
r
Horace Palla-
vicinie
. He moveth me therein to helpe to sette
forward a second contribution, not doubting
but
e first was already heere accorded: and
to signifie unto him, howe
e forces of that levie
might be best imploied, for
e benefit of these con-
treis. For
e mater of Contribution,
Mons
r
de Touraine
, was putte in good hope, at his being
in
e Hage, that
e Provinces would yeld to1000
li
ster
l
. But they shall not finde them nowe so
forward, as then they made account. For unles
it were
Holland,
w
ch
are well enough affected,
in respect of their portion, the rest of
e Provinces
will be hardly brought to any thing.
fol.281r
Of a second collection there was never no speeche,
and I hold it in vaine, to trust upon it. For as
it should a ppeere by S
r
Horaces letter, he suppo-
seth
at
e states will be drawen, to contribut great
summes, in regard of
e service, that
e armie pas-
sing this way may doe to
e contrey. Howbeit I
doe not finde, that there is any opinion in these
men heere, that
e use of those forces, can muche
advantage their estate. For they say in privat
conference, that if
e stay of
e armie should be
long in these quarters, it would turne
e contrey
to a great deale of detriment, and
e opportunitie
would be lost of assisting
e King: as on
e other
side they can reape but litle benefit, by a litle
tariance. All
e helpe
at they expect is 3 or 4
daies service in
e assault of
Bolduke,
and the
spoile, in their passage, of
e Enemies contrey.
Moreover wheras it is hoped, both by Mons
r
de Tou-
raine, and S
r
Horace Pallavicinie, that the states
will joine of their owne forces, aswell Englishe
as others, to accompany
e armie into
Fraunce,
(for they spake to me, to
at effect, when they
were at
e Hage) I signified then unto them,
and still I am persuaded, that
e states will
never yelde, that any nombers of their forces,
shall goe farther from
e Provinces, then as they
may finde a commodious retraict. What I
write unto yo
r
L. I will certifie S
r
Horace, and
of any thing besides, that I can any way con-
jecture, to be fitte for his purpose.
The bruite is muche increased of
Parmaes
reso-
lution not to goe into Fraunce: and because we
are advertised, that 40 peeces of batterie are
provided at
Andwerpe,
it is very muche suspected,
that he will give some attempt, upon
Berghen
or
fol.281v
23 Ma
r
90/1
Breda.
The want of pay among his souldiers,
doth cause a great discontentment in sundrie of
his Garrisons: as nowe we have intelligence,
of 2 Enseignes of highe Dutche in
Grave,
at
are newly mutined, and by
e rest of
at Garriso
n
driven out of
e towne.
Verdugo,
as it see-
meth, hath had some intelligence of that we
have intended against
Deventer
and
Zutphen
w
ch
he hath notified unto them, and they therupon
are very busily occupied in
e fortification of
their townes.
And thus for this present I
take my humble leave. From
e Hage.
Marche 23 1590.
Yo
r
L. most humbly bounden Tho. Bodley
